Authors:
David J. McLaughlin, T. K. Arun Kumar, Mahajabeen Padamsee,
Merje Toome-Heller, Elizabeth M. Frieders, Mary Catherine Aime
Title:
Structural Character Evolution in Pucciniomycotina: Mitosis,
Septa and Hyphal Branch Initiation in Two Helicogloea Species
Keywords:
fungal evolution, hypha, microbody, mitosis, molecular
phylogeny, septal pore, ultrastructure
Abstract:
Early diverging taxa of Ascomycota and Basidiomycota share
similarities in subcellular characters of the spindle pole body (SPB),
nuclear division and septal pore apparatus, but our understanding of
character evolution is incomplete because of the limited number of
structural studies within the earliest diverging subphyla of Dikarya,
Taphrinomycotina and Puccinomycotina. Two species of Helicogloea
(Atractiellomycetes) were analyzed for these characters and provide data
on SPB and nuclear division for an additional class of Puccinomycotina.
A detailed analysis of septal pore apparatus for the Helicogloea species
permits comparisons with those of other Pucciniomycotina and Ascomycota.
The endogenous origin of hyphal branches is shown to occur in a third
class of Puccinomycotina. The full set of characters supports a close
relationship between Atractiellomycetes and Pucciniomycetes.
